pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:0.4: 2-8. The training rules on asking for oil/honey/sugar/fish/meat/milk/curd
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.2: At that time the nuns from the group of six ate oil after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.3: … ate honey after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.4: … ate sugar after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.5: … ate fish after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.6: … ate meat after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.7: … drank milk after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.8: … ate curd after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.10: “How can nuns eat curd after asking for it?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.11: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t want tasty food?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.12: The nuns heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.13: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.14: “How can the nuns from the group of six eat curd after asking for it?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.15: “Is it true, monks, that those nuns do this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.18: How can the nuns from the group of six eat curd after asking for it?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.19: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.20: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.21: ‘If a nun asks for curd and then eats it, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.22: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.23: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.24: Soon afterwards a number of nuns were sick.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.25: The nuns who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.26: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.27: “Previously we ate curd after asking for it, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.28: But now that this has been prohibited by the Master, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.30: “Monks, I allow a sick nun to eat curd after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.31: And so, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.32: ‘If a nun who is not sick asks for (oil … honey … sugar … fish … meat … milk …) curd and then eats it, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.1.33: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.6: one who is comfortable without curd.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.8: one who is not comfortable without curd.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.10: sesame oil, mustard seed oil, honey tree oil, castor oil, oil from tallow.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.16: what lives in water is what is meant.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.18: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.20: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or milk from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.23: If she is not sick and she asks for her own benefit, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.24: When she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.25: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.26: If she is not sick, and she does not perceive herself as sick, and she eats curd after asking for it, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.27: If she is not sick, but she is unsure of it, and she eats curd after asking for it, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.28: If she is not sick, but she perceives herself as sick, and she eats curd after asking for it, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.29: If she is sick, but she does not perceive herself as sick, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.30: If she is sick, but she is unsure if she is, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.31: If she is sick, and she perceives herself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.34: if she asked for it when she was sick, but eats it when she is no longer sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.35: if she eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.37: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.38: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.39: if it is by means of her own property;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.41: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.42: The eighth training rule on acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.43: “Venerables, the eight rules on acknowledgment have been recited.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.44: In regard to this I ask you,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.50: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8:2.2.51: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment in the nuns’ analysis is finished.
